articles.headline: Brazil Reels Again as Impeachment Vote Is Declared Invalid
articles.snippet: Politicians scrambled to determine how the decision by the new speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress might affect President Dilma Rousseff’s fate.
articles.abstract: Politicians scrambled to determine how the decision by the new speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress might affect President Dilma Rousseff’s fate.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The effort to oust President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil was thrown into chaos on Monday when the new speaker of the lower house of Congress annulled a vote to impeach her, immediately upending the power struggle gripping Latin America’s largest country.

articles.headline: Ukraine Makes Iffy Progress After Trade Pact With Europe
articles.snippet: Foreign investment is sprouting along Ukraine’s western borders, but the country’s recent history of strife has made some companies hesitant to move in.
articles.abstract: Foreign investment is sprouting along Ukraine’s western borders, but the country’s recent history of strife has made some companies hesitant to move in.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUKACHEVO, Ukraine — Before gliding along trails or sliding down slopes, many of the world’s skis start at this bustling, sprawling factory in western Ukraine.

articles.headline: Conservatives Accuse Facebook of Political Bias
articles.snippet: Facebook responded to a report by the website Gizmodo that accused the social network of suppressing stories from conservative news sources.
articles.abstract: Facebook responded to a report by the website Gizmodo that accused the social network of suppressing stories from conservative news sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook scrambled on Monday to respond to a new and startling line of attack: accusations of political bias.
articles.byline: By John Herrman and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Pick for Fund-Raiser Is Rife With Contradictions
articles.snippet: Despite a tricky history, Steven Mnuchin said he jumped at the chance to be his friend’s national finance chairman.
articles.abstract: Despite a tricky history, Steven Mnuchin said he jumped at the chance to be his friend’s national finance chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street has been agog since last Thursday, when Donald Trump announced that Steven Mnuchin — who made his fortune at Goldman Sachs, worked for a firm funded by George Soros, and donated to Hillary Clinton — would be responsible for helping him raise $1 billion for Republicans and his own campaign.

articles.headline: As Lending Club Stumbles, Its Entire Industry Faces Skepticism
articles.snippet: As a wider reckoning sweeps Silicon Valley, investors and analysts are taking a more searching look at the peer-to-peer lending model.
articles.abstract: As a wider reckoning sweeps Silicon Valley, investors and analysts are taking a more searching look at the peer-to-peer lending model.
articles.lead_paragraph: Renaud Laplanche and his crew steered a 105-foot racing boat through New York Harbor one day last spring, its towering sails ripping across the water at 30 knots.

articles.headline: Donald Trump, in Switch, Turns to Republican Party for Fund-Raising Help
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s campaign took steps to expand its fund-raising resources amid concerns that the Democrats would have a big advantage in the general election.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign took steps to expand its fund-raising resources amid concerns that the Democrats would have a big advantage in the general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump took steps to appropriate much of the Republican National Committee’s financial and political infrastructure for his presidential campaign on Monday, amid signs that he and the party would lag dangerously behind the Democrats in raising money for the general election.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Ashley Parker and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Faced Choppy Waters in 2015, but Chiefs Cashed In
articles.snippet: The biggest hedge fund managers have more money and more sway than ever before, and they are wielding greater political influence.
articles.abstract: The biggest hedge fund managers have more money and more sway than ever before, and they are wielding greater political influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase paid its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, $27 million in 2015. In another Wall Street universe, the hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffin made $1.7 billion over the same year.

articles.headline: Government Must Play a Role Again in Job Creation
articles.snippet: What has stopped the United States from creating better-paying jobs is not a lack of ideas but an encrusted ideological opposition to government activism.
articles.abstract: What has stopped the United States from creating better-paying jobs is not a lack of ideas but an encrusted ideological opposition to government activism.

articles.headline: Uber Recognizes New York Drivers’ Group, Short of a Union
articles.snippet: The agreement, Uber’s latest attempt to ease concerns about its labor model, establishes benefits for drivers but stops short of unionization.
articles.abstract: The agreement, Uber’s latest attempt to ease concerns about its labor model, establishes benefits for drivers but stops short of unionization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber announced an agreement on Tuesday with a prominent union to create an association for drivers in New York that would establish a forum for regular dialogue and afford them some limited benefits and protections — but that would stop short of unionization.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Mike Isaac
